Short-Horned Lizard.FunFact: Short-horned lizards can squirt blood from their eyes when threatened.
Short-Horned Lizard.Reason: Their defensive isolation and low interaction with predators make infection improbable.

Mule Deer.FunFact: Mule deer can jump up to 8 feet in a single bound.
Mule Deer.Reason: They are extremely isolated and rarely interact with other animals long enough to transmit disease.

Yellow-Bellied Marmot.Reason: Because of their long hibernation cycle, infection probability is nearly zero — they disappear before spread is possible.

Porcupine.Reason: Their quills deter most predators, so they have very limited physical contact with other species.

Pronghorn.FunFact: Pronghorn are the second-fastest land animal on Earth.
Pronghorn.Reason: They outrun every predator — meaning the virus cannot realistically spread in gameplay conditions.

Bison.FunFact: Bison are the largest land mammals in North America.
Bison.Reason: Their thick hide and herd behavior make direct infection unlikely.

Moose.FunFact: Moose are very solitary animals except during mating season.
Moose.Reason: Because of their isolation, infection spread is statistically insignificant in Yellowstone.

Bald Eagle.FunFact: Bald eagles can spot prey up to 3 miles away.
Bald Eagle.Reason: They rarely interact physically with disease vectors, making infection unrealistic.
